questions.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine on the water is mainly due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypochlorous acid The action of Chlorine: When chlorine is added to water, hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids are formed. The alkalinity of water neutralizes hydrochloric acid. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl HOCl → H + OCl The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to the hypochlorous acid and, to a small extent, to the hypochlorite ions. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection. It is more effective (70-80 times) than the hypochlorite ion.

questions.text: Proposed guideline values for radioactivity in drinking water are:

options.label: A
options.text: Grossa activity 0.5 Bq/L & gross b activity 1Bq/L

options.label: B
options.text: Grossa activity 1 Bq/L & gross b activity 0.1Bq/L

options.label: C
options.text: Grossa activity 1 Bq/L & gross b activity 10 Bq/L

options.label: D
options.text: Grossa activity 10 Bq/L & gross b activity 1Bq/L

questions.correct_answer: A. Grossa activity 0.5 Bq/L & gross b activity 1Bq/L
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grossa activity 0.5 Bq/L & gross b activity 1Bq/L Radioactivity in drinking water should not only be kept within safe limits; it should also, within those limits, be kept as low as reasonably possible. The recommended guideline values take into account both naturally occurring radioactivity and any radioactivity that may reach the water source due to man's activities. From a radiological point of view, they represent a value below which water can be considered potable without any further radiological examination. The activity of radioactive material is the number of nuclear disintegration per unit of time. The unit of activity is a becquerel (Bq); 1 Bq = 1 disintegration per second. Formerly, the unit of activity was curie (Ci). The proposed guideline values are: Gross alpha activity 0.5 Bq / L Gross beta activity 1.0 Bq / L

questions.text: Orthotolidine test is used for detecting:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chlorine ORTHOTOLIDINE (OT) TEST – The orthotolidine test enables both free and combined chlorine in the water to be determined with speed and accuracy. When the reagent is added to water containing chlorine, it turns yellow, and the intensity of the colour varies with the gas concentration. The yellow colour is produced by both free and combined chlorine residuals. The test is carried out by adding 0.1 ml of the reagent to 1 ml of water. The yellow colour produced is matched against suitable standards or colour discs. ORTHOTOLIDINE-ARSENITE (OTA) TEST – This is a modification of the OT test to determine the separate free and combined chlorine residuals.

options.label: D
options.text: Level of residual chlorine should be 0.5mg/L

questions.correct_answer: C. Clostridial infection indicates recent infection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clostridial infection indicates recent infection Clostridial infection, or Cl.perfringens, to be more precise, regularly occurs in feces. However, in much smaller numbers than E.coli, the spores can survive in water for a longer time than organisms of the coliform group and usually resist chlorination at doses normally used in waterworks practice. Hence their presence in water denotes that fecal contamination has occurred, and their presence in the absence of coliforms denotes that contamination occurred at some remote time. The multiple tube method, also known as a presumptive coliform test, is used for bacteriological surveillance of water samples. E.coli can be tested by indole test and is the only organism producing gas from lactose at 44 degrees C. The level of residual chlorine must be 0.5mg/L in the water for successful chlorination.

questions.text: Nitrates in excess of ------- may cause infantile methemoglobinemia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50 mg/L Nitrate and nitrite: Nitrate and nitrite are naturally occurring ions that are part of the nitrogen cycle. Naturally occurring nitrate levels in surface and groundwater are generally a few milligrams per litre. Generally, vegetables are the primary source of nitrate intake when levels in drinking water are below 10 mg/litre. When the nitrate level in drinking water exceeds 50 mg/litre, drinking water will become the main source of total nitrate intake. The guideline value for nitrate in drinking water is solely to prevent methamoglobinaemia, which depends upon converting nitrate into nitrite. Bottle-fed infants of less than three months of age are most susceptible.

questions.explanation:

Contact period of at least 6 hours is essential Principles of chlorination Water to be chlorinated should be clear and free from turbidity. Turbidity impedes efficient chlorination. The chlorine demand of the water should be estimated. ( difference between chlorine added and residual chlorine remaining at the end of 1 hour at a given temperature and ph of water) The presence of free residual chlorine for a contact period of at least 1 hour is essential to kill bacteria and viruses. The minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/l for one hour.

questions.text: The vital layer in a slow sand filter is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zoogleal layer Slow sand filter / Biological filter Elements: Supernatant raw water Bed of graded sand Under drainage system System of filter control valves Vital layer: The surface of the sand bed is covered with slimy growth known as Schmutzdecke/ vital/ zoogleal or biological layer. It is slimy and gelatinous, consisting of algae, plankton, diatoms, and bacteria. The formation of a vital layer( heart of slow sand filter) is known as the ripening of the Removes organic matter, holds back bacteria & oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrate, and yields bacteria-free water.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the trickling filter:

options.label: A
options.text: It has a biological zoogleal layer

options.label: B
options.text: It acts purely as a mechanical filter

options.label: C
options.text: It is used for the primary treatment of sewage

options.label: D
options.text: It needs rest pauses for cleaning

questions.correct_answer: A. It has a biological zoogleal layer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It has a biological zoogleal layer Effluent from the primary sedimentation tank still contains a proportion of organic matter in a solution or colloidal state and numerous living organisms. It is subjected to further treatment by the trickling filter method. Over the surface and down through the filter, a very complex biological growth consisting of algae, fungi, protozoa, and bacteria of many kinds occur called as Zoogleal layer. Trickling filters do not need rest pauses because the wind blows freely through the beds supplying the oxygen the zoogleal flora needs. The action of the tricking filter is purely biological and not mechanical as suggested by the name.

questions.text: Biological oxygen demand gives an indication of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Organic matter The strength of sewage is expressed in terms of biological oxygen demand . It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sewage sample during a specified period , generally 5 days, at a specified temperature, 20QC, for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living organisms. BOD values range from 1 mg/l (natural waters) to 300 mg/l (untreated domestic sewage) BOD measures the amount of oxygen consumed by microorganisms to decompose the organic matter in the water bodies. It indicates the amount of organic pollution in an aquatic ecosystem. BOD also measures the chemical oxidation (COD) of inorganic matter. BOD is also used in sewage or wastewater treatment to destroy and decay organic wastes through aerobic organisms. It determines the amount of organic matter present in soils, sewages, sediment, garbage, sludge, etc. The biochemical oxygen demand also determines the respiration rate in living beings. BOD is also used in the medicinal & pharmaceutical industries to test the oxygen consumption of cell cultures

questions.text: The strength of sewage is expressed in terms of all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E.coli count The "strength" of the sewage is expressed in terms of BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): It is the most important test done on sewage. It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sewage sample during a specified period, generally 5 days, at a specified temperature, generally 20 deg.C, for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living organisms. BOD values range from about 1 mg per litre for natural water to about 300 mg per litre for untreated domestic sewage. If the BOD is 300 mg/l and above, sewage is said to be "strong"; if it is 100 mg/l, it is said to be "weak." CHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (COD): The COD test measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidiser. This test may be the only practical method for determining the organic load if wastes contain toxic substances. SUSPENDED SOLIDS: The suspended solids are yet another indicator of the "strength" of sewage. The amount of suspended solids in domestic sewage may vary from 100 to 500 p.p.m. (mg/I). If the amount of suspended solids is 100 mg/l, the sewage is weak; if the amount is 500 mg/l, the sewage is strong.

questions.text: All are indicators of air pollution except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

McArdle’s index McARDLE'S MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE SWEAT RATE: This is an index of thermal comfort. The other options are all indicators of Air Pollution. Some important facts about these indicators: The best indicators of air pollution are sulphur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. These are monitored on a daily basis over several sites. A central agency then collects the results. Sulphur dioxide: This gas is a major contaminant in many urban and industrial areas. Its concentration is estimated in all air pollution surveys. Smoke or Soiling index: A known air volume is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions, and the photoelectric meter measures the stain. Smoke concentration is estimated and expressed as micrograms/cubic metre of air as an average level over a period of time. Grit and dust measurement: Deposit gauges collect grit, dust, and other solids. There are analyzed monthly. Coefficient of haze: A factor used, particularly in the USA, in assessing the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air. Air pollution index: It is an arbitrary index that takes into account one or more pollutants as a measure of the severity of pollution.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man who lives alone in a poorly ventilated house without central heating uses a portable unvented kerosene heater to warm the house during the winter months. One morning, a neighbor finds him in an obtunded state. On physical examination, he appears cyanotic. Results of blood gas measurement on room air are Po2, 90 mm Hg; Pco2, 35 mm Hg; and pH, 7.3. Pulse oximetry shows low oxygen saturation. Exposure to which of the following is most likely to have produced this man’s illness?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbon monoxide Heating devices that burn hydrocarbons, such as petroleum products, generate carbon monoxide, which can build up to dangerous levels in unventilated or poorly ventilated houses. Chronic carbon monoxide poisoning produces central nervous system damage. Carbon monoxide binds much more tightly to the hemoglobin than does oxygen, resulting in hypoxia . Decreased mental functioning generally begins at carboxyhemoglobin levels greater than 20%, and death is likely at levels greater than 60%. The classic “cherry red” lividity is rare and more typical for severe acute poisoning.

Option: D. Acute exposure to beryllium may cause pneumonitis; chronic exposure results in a sarcoid-like pulmonary disease.

questions.text: Rupture of the eardrum may actually occur at a decibel level above:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

160 Deafness is the most serious pathological effect of noise. Temporary hearing loss occurs in the frequency range between 4000 and 6000 Hz. Repeated or continuous exposure to noise of around 100 decibels may result in permanent hearing loss. Non-auditory effects include interference with speech, annoyance, reduction in efficiency, and psychological changes such as a rise in BP, rise in intracranial pressure, an increase in heart rate, breathing, and sweating. Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought in from a sporting event complaining of headache, nausea, and weakness. She had been jogging outside in sunny weather where the temperature was 90° Fahrenheit with a relative humidity of 70%. She had started a training program two weeks before. She is hyperventilating, her skin is moist, and her core body temperature is 38.8° Celsius. She most likely suffers from
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heat exhaustion Heat exhaustion is what this patient is experiencing. She should be placed in a cool and shaded environment. This patient should also receive hydration and salt replenishment with IV fluids. Milder cases can be treated with oral hydration. At least 1 day of rest is recommended after heat exhaustion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Heat syncope is a sudden loss of consciousness due to vasodilation secondary to heat. Option: B. Heat cramps are characterized by painful muscle cramps, nausea, and vomiting. The core body temperature is normal. This is caused by sodium depletion due to sweating: the patient should be placed in a cool environment and hydrated with a balanced salt solution. Rest for at least 1 to 3 days is recommended. Option: D. Heat stroke is characterized by mental status changes and a core body temperature of more than 39° Celsius. The cardiovascular collapse will occur if not treated immediately, as the body temperature may reach up to 41.1° Celsius. This is a medical emergency requiring IV hydration and rapid cooling: cool water or isopropyl alcohol 70% on the body with fanning, sponge baths, ice packs on the groin/axilla/neck, and/or iced gastric lavage until the core body temperature drops to 39° Celsius. Patients should be advised to avoid heat exposure for at least 4 weeks because hypersensitivity to heat may persist for a long period of time after an episode of heat stroke.

questions.text: Heat stroke is characterized by all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Profuse sweating Heat stroke is the most serious heat-related illness. It occurs when the body becomes unable to control its temperature: its temperature rises rapidly, the sweating mechanism fails, and the body cannot cool down.it is characterized by very high body temperature, which may rise to 110°F (43.3°C) Symptoms of heat stroke Throbbing headache. Dizziness and light-headedness. Lack of sweating despite the heat. Red, hot, and dry skin. Muscle weakness or cramps. Nausea and vomiting. Rapid heartbeat, which may be either strong or weak. Rapid, shallow breathing. The outcome is often fatal. Treatment consists of rapidly cooling the body in an ice-water bath till the rectal temperature falls below 102°F (38.9°C).
